fields.value: Government Actions in a Terror Environment - Israel (GATE-Israel)

authorAffiliation.value: Department of Criminology and Criminal Justice, University of Maryland.
Josef Korbel School of International Studies, University of Denver.

dsDescriptionValue.value:
The purpose of this project is to determine the effects of repressive and conciliatory actions on Palestinian terrorist activity in Israel. The time period covered by this study, 1987-2004, includes three distinct Israeli tactical regimes, the First Intifada, the Oslo Lull, and the Second Intifada, each of which took their own approach to preventing and responding to terrorism. Data concerning Palestinian terrorist attacks was drawn from the Global Terrorism Database (GTD), in which Palestinian terrorist attacks were defined in this research as cases involving a minimum of one Israeli target in either Israel or the Palestinian territories. Data relating to Israeli state actions was found in the GATE-Israel dataset, which coded Israeli governmental actions as being conciliatory or repressive from the Palestinian perspective. Only the government actions relevant to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict are included in these data. Data were also partitioned by whether the actions were discriminate or indiscriminate. The data presented here is m
onthly counts of Palestinian terrorist actions and Israeli governmental responses that are relevant to the Palestinian conflict.

publicationCitation.value: Dugan, L., & Chenoweth, E. (2012). Moving beyond deterrence: The effectiveness of raising the expected utility of abstaining from terrorism in Israel. American Sociological Review, 77(4), 597-624.

fields.value: Subject: Study Level Error Note, Notes: The authors note that the results of practicing only conciliatory behavior cannot be determined because Israel committed at least one repressive action in each month of the study.  Additionally, GTD data for the years since and including 1998 were gathered retrospectively, likely leading to a more conservative number of attacks than if sufficient data had been gathered at the time of the attack. Because this study was conducted using open source technology terrorist events occurring in certain areas of the world may not have received as extensive news coverage as other more visible events. However, the authors note that the prominence of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict likely minimizes the effect of this phenomenon on this study.;

producerName.value: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism

distributorName.value: National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism

value: All known Israeli governmental actions towards non-state actors that occurred from June 1st, 1987 through December 31st, 2004.

fields.value: Data used for this study came from the Global Terrorism Database (GTD) and the database Government Actions in a Terror Environment-Israel (GATE-Israel).  Data concerning Palestinian terrorist attacks was drawn from the GTD, while data relating to Israeli state actions was found in GATE-Israel. Palestinian terrorist attacks were defined in this research as cases involving a minimum of one Israeli target in either Israel or the Palestinian territories. Attacks, documented in the GTD, against such targets that lack information about the perpetrators (30.2%) are assumed by this study to have been Palestinian related.  Israeli actions towards non-state actors were found by utilizing Textual Analysis by Augmented Replacement Instructions (TABARI) to search Reuters articles from January 1, 1987 to December 31, 2004 for articles containing the search term "Israel." These results were filtered again to include only articles relating to Israeli government actions, both conciliatory and repressive, towards non-state actors. To determine if actions were conciliatory or repressive, from the Palestinian perspective, the "Seven-Point Guide for the Conciliatory-Repression Scale" was developed. Data were also auto coded to reflect whether the action was discriminate or indiscriminate. The data were then divided into four temporally based sets, (1)most of the 211 months in the period with the exception of the twelve months in 1993 for which the GTD lacks data, the first four months of 1994 as they are dependent on the missing 1993 data, and the first four months of the data set because they are dependent on data outside the scope of this study; (2) those months during the First Intifada (December 1987-August 1993); (3) those months during the Oslo Lull (September 1993-August 2000); and (4) those months during the Second Intifada.
